Dear Ms. Sears:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.

ALLEGATION:
The agency has not submitted records to the Michigan Department of Health and
Human Services (MDHHS) for permanent retention one year following the final order
of adoption as required. There are five records that have not been submitted
2

INVESTIGATION:
On 5/23/2022 I reviewed the complaint, and contact was made with the complainant
via email by my Peer Consultant. I made initial contact with the agency about the
complaint via email on 5/24/2022.
On 5/25/2022, Adoption Departmental Manager (ADM) X provided information about
the complaint to me, and a Peer Consultant, via email. ADM X reported her
department had been in contact with agencies about their closed adoption records.
The department had inquired with the agencies as to the status of the closed
adoption files requested. Her department found that these files either had not been
submitted to the local office at all or were submitted outside the required timeframe
of 12 to 13 months following finalization. ADM X listed five finalized adoption files for
Methodist Children Home that may not have been submitted.
ADM X provided clarity on how the files are to be closed and sent to the County
Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) office, and the DHS-788 form to
be attached on the closed file boxes. Additionally, ADM X provided information with
respect to if an agency still has old closed adoption records outside the ones on the
list provided related to the complaint; and what that agency should do with those
records. Whether those closed records should come to ADM X’s office or the
County DHHS Office. ADM X reported, when R400.12713 was updated in 2015,
agencies were instructed to send their backlogged adoption records directly to
Central Office. She reported, it has been seven years and at this point agencies
should be caught up, and on schedule to send closed records to the local offices
between 12-13 months following finalization. If an agency still has old closed
adoption records, her office will work with the agency, accept those old records, so
as to not have the local county office bombarded with old records. She advised it
would be very helpful if the agency would include in any corrective action plan the
agency’s plan to ensure that Lansing/the department gets those old records.
On 5/25/2022, via telephone and 6/9/2022 via onsite visit, I interviewed Chief
Administrator A about the complaint. Chief Administrator A admitted to having
closed adoption files which were beyond a year after finalization that had not been
submitted to DHHS. She reported not becoming aware of the request related to the
five named adoption files until 5/3/2022. She advised the agency’s new Chief
Executive Officer (CEO) forwarded an email to her on that date. The email had
apparently been sent from State Adoption Analyst (SAA)T to the agency’s prior CEO
in April 2022, about the records. Chief Administrator A said she followed up with
SAA T via email on 5/3/2022. She inquired where/whom to send the records; but
SAA T was not able to provide the needed contact information to her. Chief
Administrator A made contact with various County DHHS offices; and as of
5/25/2022 the agency’s plans were to drop off the closed files within the next five
days.
On 6/9/2022, during my onsite visit, Chief Administrator A reported closed adoption
files for DHHS- North Central and DHHS- South Central were dropped off on
3

6/8/2022. One record related to Child 5, out of DHHS- Western Wayne, would be
dropped off on 6/10/2022. Chief Administrator A provided a copy of three closed file
tracker lists totaling 43 children’s names, whose adoption had been finalized ranging
from January 2019 to October 2020. These closed records were submitted to the
county offices on 6/8/2022. Twenty-nine were submitted to DHHS- North Central,
which included, Child 1, Child 2, Child 3 and Child 4; and 14 were submitted to
DHHS- South Central.
During my onsite visit I observed the agency’s secure storage for closed records.
Chief Administrator A reported the agency has 15-20 outstanding closed adoption
records where finalization occurred in 2019-2020, which they are working on to
submit to the department. She reported in the past they had a staff person who
handled the submission of their finalized records to Lansing/the department. She
reported the agency’s plan going forward to maintain compliance is that in the month
of December (starting this year), they will submit the finalized adoptions records for
the prior year.
Reviewed
 A copy of an adoption file records’ list from Adoption Departmental Manager X,
as referenced in this report.
 A copy of an email from SAA T to a staff person at Methodist dated 4/13/2022.
The email advised that Child 1’s, Child 2’s, Child 3’s, Child 4’s and Child 5’s
closed adoption record had not been provided to DHHS for permanent retention.
That if the record had, to please provide the date; and to respond by 4/27/2022.
 A copy of three Methodist Closed File Tracker lists, as referenced in this report:
 One list related to DHHS-South Central file submissions. It showed Chief
Administrator A’s signature for Methodist, and DHHS K’s name/signature for
DHHS-South Central. Both parties dated the form for 6/8/2022.
 The other two lists related to DHHS- North Central file submissions. Both lists
were signed and dated for 6/8/2022 by Chief Administrator A. A DHHS-North
Central staff signature was blank. Chief Administrator A reported the agency
forgot to obtain the form/ signature. She provided an email to and from
DHHS D showing documentation related to the submission, the agency
forgetting the form; and DHHS D’s thanking Chief Administrator A for the
submissions.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12713 Adoption placement record.
(5) The Michigan department of human services must
permanently retain all adoption records for children
adopted from Michigan's child welfare system. The
adoption agency must forward any adoption records for
children adopted from the Michigan child welfare system to
the department one year after finalization of the adoption.
The adoption agency may not retain the original copies or
any other copies of the adoption records.
4

ANALYSIS: The agency did not timely submit Child 1’s, Child 2’s, Child 3’s,
Child 4’s, Child 5’s, nor 38 other closed adoption files where the
respective child’s adoption had been finalized in 2019 and 2020
timely, as required by the rule. Additionally, the agency
admitted to having 15-20 other closed adoption cases on
children whose adoptions have been finalized for more than a
year. Those case submission to DHHS is pending.
The agency is in violation of the rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, continuation of the facility’s
current licensing status is recommended.
